summary: The case involves Josiah A. Short, a licensed druggist in Sierra Leone, charged with failing to maintain a register of dangerous drugs as required under the Dangerous Drugs Rules, 1929. The Police Magistrate discharged him at the close of the prosecution's case, ruling no prima facie case was established. The Attorney-General appealed to the Supreme Court, which directed conviction. On further appeal to the West African Court of Appeal, the direction to convict was set aside. The appellate court held that while the prosecution had made out a prima facie case—based on Short's status as a licensed druggist, his purchase of dangerous drugs for dispensing, prior maintenance of a register, and unaccounted use of the drugs—the Magistrate erred in discharging him without requiring a defence. The case was remitted for full hearing of the defence.
citations: Dangerous Drugs Ordinance, 1926, Ordinance No. 10 of 1926
rationaleHighlights: The phrase 'every person who supplies' includes those carrying on the business of supplying, not just actual suppliers.
A licensed druggist purchasing dangerous drugs for dispensing is prima facie a supplier under the rules.
Failure to produce a register and unaccounted use of large quantities supports a prima facie case.
The prosecution need not prove actual supply to trigger record-keeping duties.
A magistrate must call for a defence if a prima facie case exists.
Directing conviction without hearing defence violates fair trial principles.
The Supreme Court overstepped by ordering conviction pre-trial.
The appeal court remitted the case for proper trial on merits.
